awd_titl_txt: QLC: EAGER: Study of the hydrocarbon quantum formation process with carbon 12 and carbon 13 and optical control
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Mengyan Shen at University of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) is testing the hypothesis that chain hydrocarbons are quantum mechanically synthesized on a cobalt/cobalt oxide surface from carbon dioxide, water, and light.  This reaction mimics photosynthesis and is important in reducing carbon dioxide and increasing the energy supply.  The goals of this research are to exploit the characteristics of an unusual isotope distribution that is completely different from conventional expectation.  The project provides great opportunities for training students including those underrepresented in sciences.  It also helps to develop a workforce on quantum computing.  Outreach activities involving K-12 students will also be part of the funded project.  
  
A cobalt oxide photo-catalyst, discovered in Professor Shen's lab at UML, is physically activated by sunlight and has been proven to directly convert carbon dioxide and water to long-chain hydrocarbons (C5 to C15). When a mixture of isotopic C-12 and C-13 carbon dioxide was used, a highly unusual isotope distribution was observed.  Particular objectives of this proposal are (1) To confirm the observation that pure C-12 hydrocarbons and pure C-13 hydrocarbons tend to form easily on some catalysts' surfaces, which cannot be explained with the current chemical theories, (2) To understand and create a predictive model for the mechanism of the formation of chain hydrocarbons based on experimental results using isotopic carbon dioxide and isotopic water.  It is hoped that this would explain the observation of pure C-13 and pure C-12 having the tendency to group together in forming chain hydrocarbons, and (3) To find controlling parameters with light wavelength, temperature, and pressures as well as study the influence of the catalyst surface structures on the quantum formation of hydrocarbons.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this award was to exploit the characteristics of an unusual isotope distribution that is completely different from conventional expectation to convert carbon dioxide and water to long-chain hydrocarbons. The project has addressed the fundamental questions:  when a mixture of isotopic 12C and 13C carbon dioxide was used, 1) how the isotopic carbons distribute in hydrocarbon molecular chains? 2) does quantum mechanics play a role in the reaction?  and 3) what are the experimental conditions that influence the distributions?

      Carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) were converted into hydrocarbons, ranging from pentane (C5H12) to octadecane (C18H38), through an artificial photosynthesis reaction catalyzed by nanostructured Co/CoO.  The isotope effect of carbon is studied by conducting the 13C/12C competition experiments using an equal molar ratio of 13CO2 and 12CO2 as the reagents. Two anomalous isotope effects were found: 1) the dissociation of 12CO2 is easier than that of 13CO2 and 2) the same carbon isotope atoms have a relatively higher probability to bond together to form the hydrocarbon chain than  different ones do. Hot-electrons in the conduction band of CoO  quantum mechanically tunnel to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels of adsorbed CO2 molecules, which explains the first carbon isotope effect. A quantum resonant tunneling model explains the second carbon isotope effect. Since the same carbon isotopes have the same energy levels, the probability of quantum tunneling of the electrons between the same carbon isotopes is higher than the probability of quantum tunneling of electrons between different carbon isotopes. Therefore, it is observed that hydrocarbon chains with pure carbon-12 atoms or pure carbon-13 atoms are more abundant than expected. Experiments have shown that temperature, pressure as well as lattice structures of the catalyst play important roles in the isotope effects. 

      The quantum mechanical analysis of the observed isotope effect helps us to better understand the mechanism for hydrocarbon synthesis and further increase the efficiency that would alleviate the global energy problem, decrease the dependence of the United States on foreign imports and fossil fuels, and address environmental concerns such as high carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere. Since the quantum mechanics concept is common for all atoms and molecules, the results suggest that the control of temperature, pressures and catalyst may quantum mechanically synthesize larger molecules for potential applications in areas such as materials, information storage in molecules, and medicine.

      The research in this project has also contributed to nurturing multidisciplinary scientists and engineers through research-based education. A total of four students (including one undergraduate student) participated in and contributed to this project.  The PI also introduced the knowledge obtained in this project to his classes and seminars at University of Massachusetts Lowell. The research results have led to four papers published in scientific journals (one of the paper was selected as a cover art for its journal). The project also attracted students for the research in high schools and other colleges.
